levels.description: OSI Model, Topologies, and Basic Protocols

levels.description: Subnetting, Error Detection, and Flow Control

questions.question: Which class of IP address provides a maximum of only 254 host addresses per network?

Which protocol is used to map an IP address to a MAC address?
Bit stuffing is used to:
Which layer creates the 'Trailer' containing the checksum?
In Go-Back-N ARQ, if frames 4, 5, and 6 are sent, and frame 5 is lost, which frames will be resent?
The address 192.168.10.0 represents:
Which device creates separate collision domains but a single broadcast domain?
What is the CIDR notation for the subnet mask 255.255.255.0?

Flow control is the responsibility of which layers?
Which multiple access protocol is used in Ethernet (wired LAN)?
Which class of IP address is reserved for Multicasting?
How many bits are used for the Network ID in a Class B address?
What is the purpose of NAT (Network Address Translation)?
options: To translate private IP addresses to public IP addresses
questions.answer: To translate private IP addresses to public IP addresses

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid MAC address?

Which routing protocol uses Hop Count as a metric?
Checksum is used for:
If a signal has a bandwidth of 2000 Hz, what is the maximum data rate according to Nyquist theorem for a binary signal?
What happens if a collision is detected in CSMA/CD?
options: The sender stops and waits a random time (Backoff)
The sender switches to a new channel
The packet is discarded by the receiver
questions.answer: The sender stops and waits a random time (Backoff)

questions.question: The broadcast address for the network 192.168.1.0/24 is:

OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) uses which algorithm to calculate the best path?
In the TCP 3-Way Handshake, what is the correct sequence of flags exchanged?
What is the minimum size of a TCP header without options?
Which algorithm is used for Congestion Control to smooth out bursty traffic?
What is the purpose of the 'Time to Live' (TTL) field in an IP packet?
Which protocol is used by the 'Ping' command?
In IP fragmentation, which field identifies that a packet belongs to the same original message?
Which flag is set in a TCP segment to terminate a connection?
The Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) of a standard Ethernet frame is:
Which BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) is an example of which type of routing?
What is 'Piggybacking' in data communication?
options: Sending data along with the acknowledgment
questions.answer: Sending data along with the acknowledgment

questions.question: Which field in the IPv4 header allows for Quality of Service (QoS)?
In Classful addressing, which IP address is used for 'Limited Broadcast'?
Which TCP mechanism prevents a sender from overwhelming a receiver?
The combination of an IP address and a Port number is called a:
Which of the following is true about UDP?
Which port is used by SSH (Secure Shell)?
Split Horizon is a technique used to prevent:
Which protocol is used for multicasting?
In the Token Bucket algorithm, what happens if the bucket is full?
options: Tokens are stored in a buffer

questions.question: The 'Slow Start' phase is part of which mechanism?
What is the size of the UDP header?
Which protocol is responsible for resolving MAC addresses to IP addresses (Reverse of ARP)?
Which ICMP message type is sent when a destination is unreachable?
In a Token Ring network, what is needed to transmit data?
What is the maximum length of an IPv4 datagram?
Which field in the TCP header is used for Flow Control?
If a router receives a packet larger than the MTU of the next interface, and the 'Don't Fragment' (DF) bit is set, what does it do?
options: Drops the packet and sends ICMP error
questions.answer: Drops the packet and sends ICMP error

questions.question: Which algorithm is used for asymmetric key cryptography?
In SSL/TLS, which protocol is responsible for negotiating security parameters and authenticating the server?
Wireless LANs (802.11) use which mechanism to avoid collisions?
What is the 'Hidden Station Problem' in wireless networks?
options: A station is hidden behind a firewall
Two stations cannot detect each other but both can hear the access point
A station is not broadcasting its SSID
questions.answer: Two stations cannot detect each other but both can hear the access point

questions.question: Which mode of IPsec provides encryption for the entire original IP packet (including header)?
In IPv6, which address type replaces the IPv4 Broadcast address?
Which firewall type filters traffic based on the state of active connections?
What is the purpose of the RTS/CTS (Request to Send / Clear to Send) mechanism?
options: To solve the Hidden Station Problem
questions.answer: To solve the Hidden Station Problem

questions.question: Which cryptographic hash function produces a 128-bit hash value (and is considered weak)?
What is a 'Man-in-the-Middle' (MITM) attack?
options: An attacker intercepts communication between two parties
questions.answer: An attacker intercepts communication between two parties

questions.question: Which port number is used by DNS (both TCP and UDP)?
WPA2 security protocol uses which encryption standard?
In BGP, which attribute is used to prevent routing loops?
What is 'Symmetric Key Cryptography'?
options: Sender and Receiver use different keys
Sender and Receiver use the same key
questions.answer: Sender and Receiver use the same key

questions.question: Which header field in IPv6 is used to label sequences of packets requiring special handling?
A VPN (Virtual Private Network) primarily uses which protocol for tunneling?
Which wireless standard operates only in the 5 GHz band and offers very high speeds?
What is the primary function of a DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) in network security?
options: To expose public-facing services (like Web Servers) while protecting the internal LAN
questions.answer: To expose public-facing services (like Web Servers) while protecting the internal LAN

questions.question: Which attack involves sending an enormous amount of traffic to a target to shut it down?
The 'Nagle's Algorithm' is used in TCP to:
options: Reduce the number of small packets sent
questions.answer: Reduce the number of small packets sent

questions.question: Which component of PKI (Public Key Infrastructure) issues digital certificates?
What does the 'S' stand for in HTTPS?
In the Diffie-Hellman key exchange algorithm, the security relies on the difficulty of:

What is 'Anycast' routing?
Which of the following is NOT a Private IP range?
The protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses in a IPv6 network without a DHCP server is called:
Which port is used by HTTPS?
What is a 'Zero-Day Exploit'?
options: An attack that occurs at midnight
An attack exploiting a vulnerability unknown to the software vendor
An attack that takes zero seconds
questions.answer: An attack exploiting a vulnerability unknown to the software vendor

questions.question: Kerberos is an authentication protocol that uses:
HTTP/3 is based on which underlying transport protocol?
In Software Defined Networking (SDN), what is the primary architectural change?
options: Separation of Control Plane and Data Plane
questions.answer: Separation of Control Plane and Data Plane

questions.question: MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching) is often referred to as operating at which layer?
What is the main advantage of HTTP/2 over HTTP/1.1?
options: Multiplexing (sending multiple requests over a single TCP connection)
questions.answer: Multiplexing (sending multiple requests over a single TCP connection)

questions.question: VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN) is used to:
options: Create overlay networks to overcome the 4096 VLAN ID limit
questions.answer: Create overlay networks to overcome the 4096 VLAN ID limit

questions.question: What is the function of a 'Reverse Proxy'?
options: It sits in front of web servers and distributes client requests (Load Balancing/Caching)
questions.answer: It sits in front of web servers and distributes client requests (Load Balancing/Caching)

questions.question: Which protocol is lightweight and standard for IoT (Internet of Things) messaging?
In BGP, which attribute is used to influence incoming traffic to an Autonomous System (AS)?
What is 'Head-of-Line Blocking' in TCP?
options: Delay where a single lost packet blocks all subsequent packets in the stream
questions.answer: Delay where a single lost packet blocks all subsequent packets in the stream

questions.question: WebSocket protocol is primarily used for:
options: Full-duplex communication over a single TCP connection (Real-time apps)
questions.answer: Full-duplex communication over a single TCP connection (Real-time apps)

questions.question: Which of the following describes 'ARP Spoofing'?
options: An attacker sends fake ARP messages to link their MAC address with a legitimate IP
An attacker floods the network with ping requests
questions.answer: An attacker sends fake ARP messages to link their MAC address with a legitimate IP

questions.question: What is a Content Delivery Network (CDN) used for?
options: To cache content at the network edge closer to users to reduce latency
questions.answer: To cache content at the network edge closer to users to reduce latency

questions.question: The 'OpenFlow' protocol is associated with which networking technology?
In Cloud Networking, what is a VPC?
Which DNS record type specifies the Mail Server for a domain?
What does the 'Strict-Transport-Security' (HSTS) header do?
options: Forces the browser to use HTTPS only
questions.answer: Forces the browser to use HTTPS only

questions.question: Which mechanism in IPv6 replaces ARP?
What is 'Server Name Indication' (SNI)?
options: An extension to TLS that allows multiple SSL certificates on a single IP address
questions.answer: An extension to TLS that allows multiple SSL certificates on a single IP address

questions.question: In a fat-tree topology (Data Center Network), the core layer provides:
Which algorithm does STP (Spanning Tree Protocol) use to prevent loops?
What is the difference between bandwidth and throughput?
options: Bandwidth is theoretical capacity; Throughput is actual data transfer rate
Bandwidth is for wireless; Throughput is for wired
Throughput is always higher than bandwidth
questions.answer: Bandwidth is theoretical capacity; Throughput is actual data transfer rate

questions.question: Which protocol is used for synchronizing clocks over a network?
What is 'Deep Packet Inspection' (DPI)?
options: Examining the data part (payload) of a packet
questions.answer: Examining the data part (payload) of a packet

questions.question: Which IPv6 address scope is used for the local link only (not routable)?
What is the purpose of 'Keep-Alive' in HTTP/1.1?
options: To reuse the same TCP connection for multiple requests
questions.answer: To reuse the same TCP connection for multiple requests

questions.question: Which routing metric is used by EIGRP?
What is a 'Zombie' or 'Bot' in a botnet?
options: A compromised computer controlled by an attacker
questions.answer: A compromised computer controlled by an attacker
